statement.text: Atrophie blanche is a distinctive ivory-white, atrophic, stellate scar surrounded by hyperpigmentation and telangiectasias, representing CEAP class C4b and indicating dermal capillary thrombosis and infarction due to chronic venous hypertension.

explanation.intuition: Atrophie blanche represents the end-stage of localized skin infarction from small vessel disease. The white color reflects dermal fibrosis without melanin, while the surrounding pigmentation shows hemosiderin from prior extravasation. These are the scars of previous microvascular events.
explanation.key_insight: Atrophie blanche indicates significant microangiopathy and high ulceration risk. While classically associated with venous disease, it can occur in other conditions with small vessel thrombosis (livedoid vasculopathy, antiphospholipid syndrome), requiring careful evaluation of underlying etiology.
explanation.technical_details: Histologically, atrophie blanche shows dermal sclerosis, loss of appendages, hyalinized thickened capillary walls, and fibrin deposition in vessel lumens. The pathophysiology involves endothelial damage from venous hypertension, platelet activation, fibrin deposition, and small vessel thrombosis leading to localized tissue infarction and subsequent atrophic scarring.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Atrophie blanche is a healed venous ulcer. Reality: It results from dermal infarction, not ulcer healing; healed ulcers have different morphology.
Misconception: All atrophie blanche is from venous disease. Reality: Livedoid vasculopathy (primary small vessel disease) can cause identical lesions.
Misconception: Atrophie blanche is cosmetic only. Reality: It indicates significant microangiopathy and high risk of future ulceration.

presentation: Located in gaiter area, especially perimalleolar
May precede ulcer development or represent healed microvascular events
differential_diagnosis: Healed venous ulcer (different morphology, larger, scar tissue)
Radiation dermatitis (history of radiation, different distribution)
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on characteristic appearance
Duplex ultrasound to document venous disease
Biopsy if atypical or livedoid vasculopathy suspected
Hypercoagulable workup if livedoid vasculopathy suspected
Antiphospholipid antibody testing in appropriate clinical context
treatment: Wound care for any ulceration within lesions
Protect from trauma - very fragile skin

definition.@value: Ivory-white, atrophic, stellate scars of the lower leg surrounded by hyperpigmentation and telangiectasias, resulting from dermal microangiopathy and capillary thrombosis, typically in the setting of chronic venous hypertension.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

sources.article: Atrophie blanche: A distinct entity or a common finding?

learning_objectives: Distinguish atrophie blanche from other white skin lesions
Understand the microangiopathy underlying atrophie blanche
Identify when to investigate for non-venous causes
clinical_pearls: Atrophie blanche is ivory-white with surrounding hyperpigmentation and telangiectasias
Both venous disease and livedoid vasculopathy can cause identical lesions
Consider hypercoagulable workup if venous disease is minimal
High risk of ulceration - protect from trauma
Antiplatelet therapy may benefit even in venous disease
